title: Division Property of Exponents
kid_friendly_explainer: When we divide numbers or variables with exponents, we keep the base the same and SUBTRACT the exponents.
This works because division is the opposite of multiplication — if multiplying adds exponents, dividing subtracts them.
Remember: we can only divide when the base is not zero!

core_rules.name: Same base ÷ Same base
core_rules.plain_english: When dividing powers with the same base, the result is the base with exponents subtracted. Visualization Story (Buckets): Represent x^a as 'a' buckets of 'x' in the numerator, and x^b as 'b' buckets of 'x' in the denominator. Cross out one top bucket with one bottom bucket, repeating until one side is gone. Leftover buckets: If more on top → leftover buckets in numerator. If more on bottom → leftover buckets in denominator. If equal → all canceled, result = 1.

core_rules.name: Negative exponents
core_rules.plain_english: If you get a negative exponent, it means the base moves to the denominator.

core_rules.name: Alternative form
core_rules.plain_english: Dividing can also be written as flipping the base and subtracting the other way.

walkthrough: Step 3: Negative exponent means move x to denominator.

easy.directions: Simplify each expression using the rule: divide same bases → subtract exponents (top − bottom).

items.hint: Subtract exponents: 5 − 2.
Subtract exponents: 6 − 4.
a = a^1, subtract for a only.
Divide numbers and subtract x exponents.
q = q^1, subtract exponents for q.

medium.directions: Include negative exponents and multiple variables. Simplify carefully.

items.hint: Divide numbers, then subtract exponents.
Subtract each exponent: a (5−2), b (3−4).
Simplify coefficients and subtract powers.
Subtract exponents (−2 − (−5)).
Expand the top first: p^{6}q^{2}. Then divide.

challenge.directions: Include nested parentheses, zero exponents, and negatives. Write your answer with positive exponents only.

items.hint: x^0 = 1, subtract y exponents.
Expand top, then subtract exponents for each base.
Divide coefficients and subtract exponents carefully.
Multiply powers in the numerator, then subtract exponents.
Cube first: coefficients and exponents. Then divide.

extreme.directions: Complex multi-variable and fraction cases. Be cautious: apply parentheses and negative signs correctly.

items.hint: Expand both numerator and denominator before dividing.
Raise powers, then subtract exponents of a and b.
Multiply exponents first, then subtract across fraction.
Expand step by step, combine p's and q's separately.
Compute powers and coefficients carefully; track negatives.

teacher_notes: Remind students: subtract top − bottom, not the other way around!
Always rewrite negative exponents as fractions to make final answers positive.
Encourage simplifying coefficients before handling exponents.
